Description: Alabaster flask; ovoid or lentoid body; long neck and flaring rim with rounded profile; two vertical goose- or duck-head lugs or handles at side, details of eyes and beaks rendered as simple incisions; strap handle (mostly missing) from top of body to middle of neck; formed through both carving and grinding with an abrasive; surface corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Curium
Curator's comments: According to Jacobsson (Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus, pp. 18 and 80) this object is both unique to Cyprus and lacks close parallels elsewhere, though individual features, such as the lentoid body and lug handles, can be attested elsewhere in 18th Dynasty contexts (Petrie, Stone and metal vases, London 1937, PLS. XXXVI:919 & XXXIV:882; Hayes, The sceptre of Egypt II. The Hyksos period and the New Kingdom (1675-1080 BC), 1959, pp. 207, 209 fig. 123)
Bibliographic references: Jacobsson 1994 / Aegyptiaca from Late Bronze Age Cyprus (No. 201)
Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p. 80 Tomb 89, no. 7)
SCE IV/1D / The Swedish Cyprus Expedition. Vol. IV. Part 1D. The Late Cypriot Bronze Age. Other arts and crafts (p. 544)
